Award.AwardTitle: Dielectric Photomasks for Nanopatterning Arbitrary Molecular Orientations

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Controlling molecular orientations is an essential step in manufacturing liquid crystal devices, such as liquid crystal displays where rod-shaped molecules need to be aligned in a uniform direction at substrate surfaces. Many emerging liquid crystal applications, such as flat optical elements, stimuli-responsive materials and devices rely on spatially varying molecular orientations. As a result, scalable manufacturing techniques for patterning molecular orientations are in high demand. Recently a projection photopatterning technique using specially designed photomasks made of nanometer-sized rectangular holes in aluminum films was shown capable of photo-aligning molecular orientations into complex patterns, promising scalable manufacturing of various liquid crystal devices. However, this kind of metallic photomask suffers from low efficiency in optical transmission, especially for ultra-violet light. This award supports fundamental research to develop high efficiency photomasks by using nanostructures of dielectric materials, and facilitates practical deployment of this photopatterning technique in liquid crystal device manufacturing. The project studies photo-patterning of complex structures with ordered molecular orientations using ultra-violet light and the dielectric metamasks. The research is interdisciplinary, involving photomask design, numerical simulations, liquid crystal materials and devices, nanomanufacturing and optical characterization. The PI will leverage the research to educate graduate and undergraduate students with multidisciplinary knowledge and skills, and to enhance diversity and STEM education by involving minority and high-school students.

Plasmonic metamasks that can generate spatially-varying patterns of both light intensity and polarization direction have recently been suggested and utilized for photoaligning molecular orientations into complex spatially varying patterns. One issue with the plasmonic metamasks is that Ohmic losses in plasmonic materials make the optical transmission low. This project aims to eliminate this limit by developing dielectric metamasks. This research includes simulation, fabrication and characterization of dielectric metamasks with designable polarization patterns and high optical transmission in ultra-violet and near ultra-violet wavelength ranges; building of an optical photopatterning system; and designing, fabrication and characterization of Pancharatnam-Berry microlens arrays and mirrors as testbeds. The research advances basic understanding and new knowledge on designing dielectric metamasks and capabilities in scalable fabrication of liquid crystal devices such as geometric phase optical elements. Success of this project is expected to increase spatial resolution and throughput of the metamask-based photopatterning technique. The research outcomes should enrich the nanomanufacturing toolbox and facilitate practical applications of Pancharatnam-Berry flat optical elements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Liquid crystals brought about an informational revolution in recent years, enabling portable display applications.  This project aimed to unveil the tremendous potential of liquid crystals for new applications, such as ultrathin planar optical elements. These emerging applications require to design liquid crystal materials with well-controlled spatially-varying molecular orientations. A scalable manufacturing technique to align liquid crystal molecules into spatially non-uniform patterns is therefore in high demand.

The project developed a newly proposed technique of molecular photoalignment based on plasmonic metamasks. A metamask represents a thin metal film with elongated nanoslits. A light beam passing through the slits becomes linearly polarized along the long axis of the slit. This patterned polarization is used to illuminate a layer of photosensitive azo-dye molecules that realign perpendicularly to the polarization direction. The photoaligned azo-dye substrate is then used to align the liquid crystals.  Since the polarization field could be predesigned in any geometry by designing the arrays of nanoslits, the resulting molecular orientation of the liquid crystal could be manufactured with a predetermined pattern.  Researchers developed an approach to characterize the strength of photoalignment, which is determined by the so-called anchoring coefficient. The coefficient was determined by measuring how the actual molecular orientation differs from the imprinted orientation. 

To demonstrate the utility of the photoalignment of liquid crystals, the researchers used plasmonic metamasks to fabricate novel planar optical elements, such as Pancharatnam-Berry microlens arrays. The technique was applied to align liquid crystals of two types, thermotropic and lyotropic.  The thermotropic liquid crystals are based on oil-like organic materials that change their properties when the temperature changes. The studied lyotropic liquid crystals are organic molecules that show collective orientational order when dispersed in water.   The patterned molecular orientation was used to create a complex topology of the liquid crystal medium with a network of defect lines, called disclinations.  The patterns also allowed the researchers to control the trajectories of microswimmers placed in a liquid crystal. An advantage of the plasmonic metamasks for manufacturing is that one metamask can be used thousands, if not millions, of times without degradation: its role is to transmit a portion of light, a task that does not degrade the material.

The intellectual merit of the project is in deepening scientific knowledge of molecular scale alignment and in the development and characterization of a new nanomanufacturing technique for various devices that require spatially variable molecular orientations. These advances will not only enrich the nanomanufacturing toolbox but also facilitate practical applications such as the development and manufacturing of elements for planar optics.

The multidisciplinary research that combined physics, optics, and materials science provided a great platform to educate graduate and undergraduate students in liquid crystal materials science and technology, nanophotonics, micro/nanofabrication, optical microscopic imaging, and characterization, and numerical modeling. The educational and outreach activities were tied closely to the research efforts, integrating the new knowledge onto the graduate-level courses, recruiting and mentoring talented high-school students as research interns through Kent State’s College Credit Plus program; disseminating the research findings to the scientific community, industry, and general public, increasing diversity of participating groups, through training of two female graduate students.
